text: [Music]
I think the media has a share of
responsibility
for not getting at the nub of the most
difficult question of all in the
beginning of the war and that's weapons
of mass destruction. No one, no one,
save some pieces in Night Rider and a
few other places cast sufficient doubt
of of that crucial issue to halt that
freight train that was the Bush
administration. And it was a it was an
ideological freight train. I don't think
opinion journalism was going to halt
that freight train of the Bush
administration. I think the only thing
that could possibly conceivably have
derailed it is if somehow investigative
reporting had discovered that the entire
WMD thing was a sham. And it was a sham
and and a historical sham.
Um and no one uh in a way sufficient and
large enough despite some some excellent
efforts including night rider clearly
did that. You know, I think clearly
um there's been more self-laceration and
self-examination in the journalistic
world than in the White House. Clearly,
you know, if you take a publication like
The New Yorker and ask if we got
collectively WMD question right, the
answer is absolutely not. And then if
you ask the question, were we light on
the Bush administration? I don't think
that that is the case.
Um, I think that we've been positively
brutal on the Bush administration in
recent years, both in the investigative
sense as well as the easier opinion
sense, you know, and it's not just
Seymour Hirs, it's Jane Mayor, it's
George Packer, it's uh any number of any
number of individual voices as well as
the the collective uh presentation of
the magazine. I'll be very very clear. I
wrote one comment saying that the George
Bush administration had not made a clear
case to go to war in Iraq, but that
Kenneth Pollock had made a much clearer
case, and if we're going to go to war in
Iraq, we need a case to be made. Uh Rick
Herzburg was against the war in comment
after comment after comment. Um so the
notion that we were pro-war, I think, is
is, you know, off base. This is not the
national review or uh the Washington
Post editorial uh page. Uh even so I
think the comment that I wrote in in the
view of hindsight is was totally off
base. Uh we had cover after cover that
was uh critical and certainly the
subsequent reporting that came after the
war and on on after the war commenced
after the invasion was extremely
critical. Um so you know the New Yorker
is not an opinion magazine. It's not the
nation on the left or um the Weekly
Standard on the right. The the core of
it um is its reporting where politics is
concerned. And there um I deeply regret
that we like everybody else and again
there are reasons for this. I mean the
to review uh it wasn't just the American
intelligence community that said they
were WMD in Iraq. the Israelis, the
Germans, the French um all said that
there had been WMD and there was good
reason for it because there had been at
a certain point and they had been used
against the Kurds against weapons used
against the Israelis uh invasion of a
neighbor. This was not exactly uh a
nation uh known for its uh sense of uh
international uh ethics or good
behavior.
So uh and what and what's more, Saddam
Hussein wanted to fool his own hierarchy
into thinking that it had these weapons
in order to strengthen his hold on
power. That's how perverse uh he was and
that's how hard a story that was to get.
And for individual reporters to get that
story when all these intelligence
agencies were saying otherwise is is if
not impossible then very difficult.
[Music]
